column4: @CamilleSchrier has been an advocate for reducing opioid abuse, medication errors, and the associated mortality of both by educating across communities and demographics, from pediatrics to geriatrics. Thank you, Camille, for your work in fighting against the addiction epidemic.
I had the pleasure of joining members of our Korean American community for a virtual roundtable to discuss the impact of COVID-19. https://t.co/ajeu0P3dpT

I had the opportunity to join a dedication ceremony in Lansdale to honor the legacy Dr. Frank Boston and his impact in the medical field and within our community as the founder of North Penn Hospital. 

The legacy of Dr. Boston is one worth emulating during these difficult times. https://t.co/tE3g70yAFg

October 15 to December 7 is when all people with Medicare can change their Medicare health plans and prescription drug coverage for the following year to better meet their needs. (2/2)

https://t.co/Uchqpkvtcf

Once a year, Medicare beneficiaries across the country have a chance to look at their health insurance coverage, shop around, and switch to another plan if they choose. (1/2)

https://t.co/HsISAPaLJG

Right now, individuals with hearing, communication, and swallowing disorders face an even higher risk for isolation and depression, Medicare beneficiaries need access to appropriate telehealth services to slow transmission of COVID-19.

Today is #WorldMentalHealthDay.

It is unacceptable that the @USTreasury and the @SBAgov guidelines had no revenue loss requirements, and only required an attestation that a business was “negatively impacted” by #COVID19.

Businesses that depend on foot traffic and direct in-person contact, like small restaurants, are the businesses that are now insolvent because of this pandemic, and these companies account for nearly 50% of our nation’s workforce. (8/9)

Banks were also receiving applications from businesses that are not small, do not rely on foot traffic and are not insolvent, like hedge funds and brokerage businesses, who in some cases received as much as $10M in forgivable loans. (3/9)

Local chambers of commerce need support during these difficult times. They continue to help small businesses navigate the current economic downturn spurred by the #COVID19 pandemic. Without support, they will be unable to survive and help our community.
